```c
static int irq(void)
{
	int rc = 0;
	char *err_msg="";
	enum metal_log_level mll= metal_get_log_level();
	int i, tst_irq[2];

	/* Do not show LOG_ERROR or LOG_DEBUG for expected fail case */
	metal_set_log_level(METAL_LOG_CRITICAL);

	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		/* we only want to test the lib API, so create 'virtual' IRQs */
		tst_irq[i] = eventfd(0,0);
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s: irq %d associated with fd %d\n",
			  __func__, i, tst_irq[i]);
	}

	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[1], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 1 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}

	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 after unregistering failed\n";
		goto out;
	}
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[1]);

out:
	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		close(tst_irq[i]);
	}
	metal_set_log_level(mll);
	if ((err_msg[0] != '\0') && (!rc))
		rc = -EINVAL;
	if (rc) metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s", err_msg);
	return rc;
}
```

int metal_irq_register(int irq,
		       metal_irq_handler irq_handler,
		       void *arg)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	struct metal_irq *irq_data;

	cntr = metal_irq_get_controller(irq);
	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	if (cntr->irq_register != NULL) {
		return cntr->irq_register(cntr, irq, irq_handler, arg);
	}
	if (cntr->irqs == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	irq_data = &cntr->irqs[irq - cntr->irq_base];
	irq_data->hd = irq_handler;
	irq_data->arg = arg;
	return 0;
}

static struct metal_irq_controller *metal_irq_get_controller(int irq)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		int irq_base, irq_end;

		cntr = (struct metal_irq_controller *)
		       metal_container_of(node, struct metal_irq_controller,
					  node);
		irq_base = cntr->irq_base;
		irq_end = irq_base + cntr->irq_num;
		if (irq >= irq_base && irq < irq_end) {
			return cntr;
		}
	}
	return NULL;
}
...
static int irq_handler(int irq, void *priv)
{
	(void)irq;
	(void)priv;

	return 0;
}

explanation:
I flagged all call sites and code constructs that could participate in direct or indirect recursion: calls from irq() to metal_irq_register/metal_irq_unregister, the assignment of handler pointers in metal_irq_register, the cntr->irq_register invocation (which may call back into the IRQ subsystem), and the metal_log macro (which invokes a log handler function pointer). These are the only locations where function pointers are stored or invoked or where external/implementation-defined callbacks may be executed, so they must be inspected for possible recursive call paths.

The other fragments in the provided code do not need investigation for Rule 17.2: local variable declarations and simple assignments, the loop structure that creates virtual IRQs, the eventfd and close system calls (they do not call back into the presented functions), the literal goto/out cleanup pattern, and the trivial metal_irq_get_controller implementation (it merely searches a list and returns a controller, it does not call metal_irq_register or irq). The irq_handler shown is empty and does not call back into irq() or metal_irq_register. The assignment of handler pointer (irq_data->hd = irq_handler) in metal_irq_register is not a call itself — only the cntr->irq_register and any invoked log handler are potential call sites for indirect recursion, and those have been included above. Therefore the listed fragments cover all code locations that could create direct or indirect recursion given the provided code.
